hints_html:
A bad function in the integrand will look much better when it is differentiated. Is there an integration technique that involves a differentiation step?

Try integration by parts.
hints_latex:
A \emph{bad} function in the integrand will look much better when it is
differentiated. Is there an integration technique that involves a
differentiation step?
hints_raw:
A ''bad'' function in the integrand will look much better when it is differentiated. Is there an integration technique that involves a differentiation step?
Try integration by parts.
question: 3 (a)
sols_html:
The bad part of the integrand is \(\ln x\). The hints says we’d like to differentiate it (to make it 1/x). The relevant integration technique that involves differentiation is then integration by parts. First we identify \(u=\ln x\) and \(dv=1/x^{101} dx\), then, \(v=-1/ (100 x^{100})\) by anti-differentiation, and \(du=(1/x)dx\) by diffentiation. It seems we are not getting an integral that is harder then before, so let’s move on and apply integration by parts:

\[\begin{aligned} \int\frac{\ln x}{x^{101}}dx &= \int udv=uv-\int vdu\\ &= -\frac{1}{100}\frac{\ln x}{x^{100}}-\int\left(-\frac{1}{100}\frac{1}{x^{100}}\right)\left(\frac{1}{x}dx\right)\\ &= -\frac{1}{100}\frac{\ln x}{x^{100}}+\frac{1}{100}\int\frac{1}{x^{101}}dx\\ &= \frac{1}{100}\left(-\frac{\ln x}{x^{100}}-\frac{1}{100}\frac{1}{x^{100}}\right)+C\\ &= -\frac{1}{100x^{100}}\left(\ln x+\frac{1}{100}\right)+C\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
The \emph{bad} part of the integrand is $\ln x$. The hints says we'd
like to differentiate it (to make it 1/x). The relevant integration
technique that involves differentiation is then \emph{integration by
parts}. First we identify $u=\ln x$ and $dv=1/x^{101} dx$, then,
$v=-1/ (100 x^{100})$ by anti-differentiation, and $du=(1/x)dx$ by
diffentiation. It seems we are not getting an integral that is harder
then before, so let's move on and apply integration by parts:

\begin{align*}
\int\frac{\ln x}{x^{101}}dx 
 &= \int udv=uv-\int vdu\\
 &= -\frac{1}{100}\frac{\ln x}{x^{100}}-\int\left(-\frac{1}{100}\frac{1}{x^{100}}\right)\left(\frac{1}{x}dx\right)\\
 &= -\frac{1}{100}\frac{\ln x}{x^{100}}+\frac{1}{100}\int\frac{1}{x^{101}}dx\\
 &= \frac{1}{100}\left(-\frac{\ln x}{x^{100}}-\frac{1}{100}\frac{1}{x^{100}}\right)+C\\
 &= -\frac{1}{100x^{100}}\left(\ln x+\frac{1}{100}\right)+C
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
The ''bad'' part of the integrand is <math>\ln x</math>. The hints says we'd like to differentiate it (to make it 1/x). The relevant integration technique that involves differentiation is then ''integration by parts''. First we identify <math>u=\ln x</math> and <math>dv=1/x^{101} dx</math>, then, <math>v=-1/ (100 x^{100})</math> by anti-differentiation, and <math>du=(1/x)dx</math> by diffentiation. It seems we are not getting an integral that is harder then before, so let's move on and apply integration by parts:

:<math>
\begin{align}
\int\frac{\ln x}{x^{101}}dx 
 &= \int udv=uv-\int vdu\\
 &= -\frac{1}{100}\frac{\ln x}{x^{100}}-\int\left(-\frac{1}{100}\frac{1}{x^{100}}\right)\left(\frac{1}{x}dx\right)\\
 &= -\frac{1}{100}\frac{\ln x}{x^{100}}+\frac{1}{100}\int\frac{1}{x^{101}}dx\\
 &= \frac{1}{100}\left(-\frac{\ln x}{x^{100}}-\frac{1}{100}\frac{1}{x^{100}}\right)+C\\
 &= -\frac{1}{100x^{100}}\left(\ln x+\frac{1}{100}\right)+C
\end{align}
</math>
